documents.t: How can I enable the GPU Widget?
Override specific fields, by providing your desired value with the following options.
Number needs to be passed in GHz (e.g. 2.8) type: number default: unset
Number needs to be passed in bytes (e.g. 34359738368 for 32 GB, because it is 32 * 1024 * 1024 * 1024) type: number default: unset
Number needs to be passed in bit (e.g. 100000000 for 100 Mb/s, because it is 100 * 1000 * 1000) type: number default: unset
Number needs to be passed in bit (e.g. 100000000 for 100 Mb/s, because it is 100 * 1000 * 1000) type: number default: unset
Number needs to be passed in Megabit (e.g. 10000 for 10 GB/s, because it is 10 * 1000) type: number default: unset

Pass a comma-separated list of brands of your drives. You can skip correct drives, by passing empty values for it (e.g. Samsung,,WD would result in Samsung for Drive 1 and WD for Drive 3). type: string default: unset

Pass a comma-separated list of sizes of your drives. You can skip correct drives, by passing empty values for it (e.g. 123,,321 would result in 123 for Drive 1 and 321 for Drive 3). Number needs to be passed in bytes (e.g. 34359738368 for 32 GB, because it is 32 * 1024 * 1024 * 1024). type: string default: unset

Pass a comma-separated list of types of your drives. You can skip correct drives, by passing empty values for it (e.g. SSD,,HDD would result in SSD for Drive 1 and HDD for Drive 3). type: string default: unset

Pass a comma-separated list of brands of your GPUs. You can skip correct GPUs, by passing empty values for it (e.g. Intel,,Nvidia would result in Intel for GPU 1 and Nvidia for GPU 3). type: string default: unset

Pass a comma-separated list of models of your GPUs. You can skip correct GPUs, by passing empty values for it (e.g. CometLake-H GT2,,GeForce GTX 1650 Ti would result in CometLake-H GT2 for GPU 1 and GeForce GTX 1650 Ti for GPU 3). type: string default: unset

Pass a comma-separated list of memory-sizes of your GPUs. You can skip correct GPUs, by passing empty values for it (e.g. 4096,,256 would result in 4 GiB for GPU 1 and 256 MiB for GPU 3). type: string default: unset

To use the GPU widget, make sure to include it in the DASHDOT_WIDGET_LIST. One limitation with the GPU widget is that it will only run out of the box with from source installations. Docker images do not include the necessary tools (mainly, because I don't want to bloat the image for everyone). If you absolutely need the GPU widget running inside a docker container, you will need to create your own image. These links might help you with that: https://www.howtogeek.com/devops/how-to-use-an-nvidia-gpu-with-docker-containers/ https://docs.docker.com/compose/gpu-support/ https://towardsdatascience.com/how-to-properly-use-the-gpu-within-a-docker-container-4c699c78c6d1 https://stackoverflow.com/q/25185405/9150652 https://stackoverflow.com/q/63751883/9150652

Change the order of the labels in the list, to change the position in the widget, or remove an item from the list, to remove it from the widget (The available options are: brand, model, memory). type: string default: brand, model, memory
To adjust the relative size of the GPU widget. type: number default: 6
To adjust the minimum width of the GPU widget (in px). type: number default: 700
The amount of datapoints in the GPU graph. type: number default: 20
Read the GPU load every x milliseconds. type: number default: 1000

Change the order of the labels in the list, to change the position in the widget, or remove an item from the list, to remove it from the widget (The available options are: brand, size, type, frequency). type: string default: brand,size,type,frequency
To adjust the relative size of the Memory widget. type: number default: 4
To adjust the minimum width of the Memory widget (in px). type: number default: 500
The amount of datapoints in the Memory graph. type: number default: 20
Read the Memory load every x milliseconds. type: number default: 1000

Change the order of the labels in the list, to change the position in the widget, or remove an item from the list, to remove it from the widget (The available options are: brand, model, cores, threads, frequency). type: string default: brand,model,cores,threads,frequency
To adjust the relative size of the Processor widget. type: number default: 4
To adjust the minimum width of the Processor widget (in px). type: number default: 500
The amount of datapoints in the Processor graph. type: number default: 20
Read the Processor load every x milliseconds. type: number default: 1000
At which interval the network speed-test should be rerun (in minutes). type: number default: 60

Change the order of the labels in the list, to change the position in the widget, or remove an item from the list, to remove it from the widget (The available options are: type, speed_up, speed_down, interface_speed, public_ip). type: string default: type,speed_up,speed_down,interface_speed
To adjust the relative size of the Network widget. type: number default: 6
To adjust the minimum width of the Network widget (in px). type: number default: 500
The amount of datapoints in each of the Network graphs. type: number default: 20
Read the Network load every x milliseconds. type: number default: 1000
You can use the DASHDOT_WIDGET_LIST to add the GPU widget, by passing a list that includes it (e.g. os,cpu,storage,ram,network,gpu).
documents.s: How can I enable the GPU Widget?

documents.t: If you think there is no answer for your question and it is actually a bug, or a missing feature, please create a new Issue on GitHub. If you need further help, please join our Discord - we are happy to answer any questions.

Change the order of the labels in the list, to change the position in the widget, or remove an item from the list, to remove it from the widget (The available options are: brand, size, type). type: string default: brand,size,type
To adjust the relative size of the Storage widget. type: number default: 3.5
To adjust the minimum width of the Storage widget (in px). type: number default: 500
Read the Storage load every x milliseconds. type: number default: 60000

Change the order of the labels in the list, to change the position in the widget, or remove an item from the list, to remove it from the widget (The available options are: os, arch, up_since). type: string default: os,arch,up_since
To adjust the relative size of the OS widget. type: number default: 1.5
To adjust the minimum width of the OS widget (in px). type: number default: 300
Config options can optionally passed using the --env flag. docker container run -it \ --env DASHDOT_ENABLE_CPU_TEMPS "true" \ # ...

version: '3.5'services: dash: image: mauricenino/dashdot:latest restart: unless-stopped privileged: true ports: - '80:3001' volumes: - /etc/os-release:/etc/os-release:ro - /proc/1/ns/net:/mnt/host_ns_net:ro - /media:/mnt/host_media:ro - /mnt:/mnt/host_mnt:ro
Config options can optionally set, by using the environment field. services: dash: environment: DASHDOT_ENABLE_CPU_TEMPS: 'true' # ...
To run this repository from source, you need to have the following installed: node.js (recommended version 18.x) yarn git speedtest (recommended) or alternatively: speedtest-cli

After that, download and build the project (might take a few minutes) git clone https://github.com/MauriceNino/dashdot &&\ cd dashdot &&\ yarn &&\ yarn build:prod When done, you can run the dashboard by executing: sudo yarn start
Config options can optionally passed using environment variables. export DASHDOT_PORT="8080" &&\ sudo yarn start
There are two endpoints which can be used to retrieve data about the running dash. instance:
Gives information about the static data of the running instance. Mostly needed to read the speed-test result at network.speedDown and network.speedUp. Example: https://<YOUR_SERVER_URL>/info

Gives information about the configurations of the runnning instance. Mostly needed to read the enabled widgets at config.widget_list, or if multi-view for the storage widget is enabled at config.enable_storage_split_view. Example: https://<YOUR_SERVER_URL>/config
URL Info https://dash.mauz.io/info null Config https://dash.mauz.io/config null

You can implement your running dash. instance on your websites and personal dashboards, via iframes that can be configured using query parameters. <iframe src="https://<YOUR_SERVER_URL>/?singleGraphMode=true&graph=cpu&multiView=true" style="border-radius: 20px"></iframe>
This parameter tells dash. that it should only show a single graph in full-screen mode. type: boolean required: true
Select the specific graph that you want to show, type: string (cpu, storage, ram, network, gpu) required: true

For the cpu and storage widgets, there are multi-device views. These can be shown, by passing this parameter. type: boolean caution The multi-view for the storage widget is opt-in. To check if the installation has this enabled, use the API Request to /config, like described in the API Section
To override the theme of the graph. If this is not passed, the default theme of the users browser is used. type: string (dark, light)
To override the color of the graph, passed as a hex string. If this is not passed, the default color of the widget is used. The color needs to be passed without the trailing #. type: string
To override the background color, passed as a hex string. If this is not passed, the default color of the theme is used. The color needs to be passed without the trailing #. type: string

This changes the border-radius on the graphs. This is mainly needed to add border-radius on views with multiple graphs, like the network graph. If you want to add a bigger border-radius to the whole container, just add it to the iframe's styles. type: number
This changes the gap between the graphs. This is mainly needed on views with multiple graphs, like the network graph. type: number

URL Widget Multi-View Theme Primary Color # Surface Color # Outer Radius px Inner Radius px Gap px Result <iframe src="https://dash.mauz.io?singleGraphMode=true&graph=cpu&multiView=false&innerRadius=10" style="border-radius: 20px"></iframe>
